article.description: Michael Lindeman scored 20 points, including two 3-pointers late in the game, and No. 13 Creighton held off Northern Iowa 84-75 on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Creighton has to battle, but beats everyone to 20th win
article.linkText: First to 20: Creighton sprints on, topping Northern Iowa
article.story: OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- Creighton's 84-75 victory over Northern Iowa on Tuesday night made the Bluejays the first Division I team to reach 20 wins this season. There was no celebrating in the locker room, though. In fact, the 13th-ranked Bluejays got a stern lecture from coach Dana Altman after what he considered an uninspired effort. "The whole team is a little disappointed,'' Altman said. "I want them to be a little disappointed. Heck, we've got eight games left, and we didn't make progress tonight.'' Michael Lindeman scored a career-high 20 points, including two key 3-pointers late in the game, and the Bluejays (20-2, 10-1 Missouri Valley Conference) shot 57.4 percent. But the Panthers (6-13, 3-8), who rank no higher than sixth in any MVC offensive category, shot 51.7 percent and got a career-high 26 points from freshman Ben Jacobson. "I'm just really embarrassed about what happened tonight, for me and for our team,'' said Kyle Korver, who scored 16 points but was held to 4-of-10 shooting. "That was not good basketball. UNI played well, and Jacobson played really well, but that guy has no business coming in getting those points. That's really frustrating and it's not going to happen again.'' The Panthers, who led 36-35 at halftime, never let Creighton make a decisive run until the final minutes. "They've blown people out of here with runs, and we really avoided that all night long,'' Panthers coach Greg McDermott said. Nate Funk's jump shot in the lane with 7:47 left put Creighton ahead to stay, at 66-64, and started a 9-1 surge. After Funk's basket, Brody Deren swatted away Chris Foster's shot on the other end, then Lindeman swished a 3-pointer from the corner to bring the Civic Auditorium crowd of 8,827 to its feet. The Panthers pulled to 76-72 on a basket by Matt Schneiderman, but Lindeman responded with a long 3-pointer -- his third of the game -- with 1:21 left to push Creighton's lead back to seven points. Forward Mike Grimes gave the Bluejays a spark, scoring all six of his points in the final 5:47 and grabbing six of his game-high seven rebounds in the second half. "We made plays down the stretch when we needed to,'' Altman said. "At times we just didn't have the energy or focus I thought we needed. We had trouble getting a rhythm tonight. Northern had a lot to do with it. We had a hard time shutting them down.'' Lindeman, averaging 7.6 points, had scored a then-career-high 15 points in the Bluejays' 65-52 win at Northern Iowa on Dec. 4. He emerged again Tuesday as Northern Iowa freshman John Little never let Korver get much more than an arm's distance away. "They put so much pressure on Kyle that it gives a lot of opportunities for some other people,'' Lindeman said. Deren was 5-of-7 from the field and had 10 points. David Gruber scored 14 points for Northern Iowa before fouling out with 2:50 left. The Panthers dictated the pace in the first half after overcoming an early deficit. Jacobson scored six points and Matt Bennett had five in a 16-1 run that gave the Panthers a 21-14 lead. But Korver drilled a 3-pointer, Tyler McKinney scored off his steal of an inbounds pass and Larry House hit a 15-footer to tie the score. The teams traded baskets before Gruber scored six straight points as the Panthers moved out to their one-point lead at the break, the third time this season the Bluejays trailed after 20 minutes. "We can't play much better basketball,'' McDermott said. "I told our guys in the locker room that we have absolutely nothing to hang our heads about.''
